merged_prs.title: 0xdead10cc crash fix
merged_prs.body: ## Summary This commit fixes the background crashes with termination code 0xdead10cc. Those crashes were caused by the fact that NostrDB was being stored on the shared app container (Because our app extensions need NostrDB data), and iOS kills any process that holds a file lock after the process is backgrounded. Other developers in the field have run into similar problems in the past (with shared SQLite databases or shared SwiftData), and they generally recommend not to place those database in shared containers at all, mentioning that 0xdead10cc crashes are almost inevitable otherwise: - https://ryanashcraft.com/sqlite-databases-in-app-group-containers/ - https://inessential.com/2020/02/13/how_we_fixed_the_dreaded_0xdead10cc_cras.html Since iOS aggressively backgrounds and terminates processes with tight timing constraints that are mostly outside our control (despite using Apple's recommended mechanisms, such as requesting more time to perform closing operations), this fix aims to address the issue by a different storage architecture. Instead of keeping NostrDB data on the shared app container and handling the closure/opening of the database with the app lifecycle signals, keep the main NostrDB database file in the app's private container, and instead take periodic read-only snapshots of NostrDB in the shared container, so as to allow extensions to have recent NostrDB data without all the complexities of keeping the main file in the shared container. This does have the tradeoff that more storage will be used by NostrDB due to file duplication, but that can be mitigated via other techniques if necessary. Closes: https://github.com/damus-io/damus/issues/2638 Closes: https://github.com/damus-io/damus/issues/3463 Changelog-Fixed: Fixed background crashes with error code 0xdead10cc Signed-off-by: Daniel D’Aquino ## Checklist ### Standard PR Checklist - [x] I have read (or I am familiar with) the [Contribution Guidelines](../docs/CONTRIBUTING.md) - [x] I have tested the changes in this PR - [x] I have profiled the changes to ensure there are no performance regressions, or I do not need to profile the changes. - Utilize Xcode profiler to measure performance impact of code changes. merged_prs.title: fix: clear DH shared secrets after Noise handshake operations
merged_prs.body:
## Summary
- Fixed 6 locations in `NoiseProtocol.swift` where `secureClear()` was missing after DH key agreement operations
- Added `TrackingMockKeychain` to verify secureClear calls in tests
- Added 3 new tests to verify proper secret clearing

## Problem
4 of 8 DH operations in the Noise protocol weren't clearing shared secrets from memory after use. This breaks forward secrecy guarantees - if memory is later compromised, past session keys could be recovered.

## Solution
Added `secureClear()` calls for all DH operations:
- `writeMessage()`: .es (initiator/responder), .se (initiator/responder)
- `performDHOperation()`: .ee and .ss operations

Pattern applied:
```swift
let shared = try localEphemeral.sharedSecretFromKeyAgreement(with: remoteStatic)
var sharedData = shared.withUnsafeBytes { Data($0) }
symmetricState.mixKey(sharedData)
keychain.secureClear(&sharedData)
```

## Test plan
- [x] All existing NoiseProtocolTests pass
- [x] New `secureClearCalledDuringHandshake` test verifies secureClear is called at least 6 times
- [x] New `encryptionWorksAfterSecureClear` test verifies encryption still works
- [x] New `secureClearCalledInBothWriteAndReadPaths` test verifies both paths clear secrets

merged_prs.title: fix: add thread safety to NostrTransport read receipt queue
merged_prs.body:
## Summary
- Added barrier synchronization for `readQueue` and `isSendingReadAcks` in NostrTransport
- Created new test file with 3 thread safety tests

## Problem
The `readQueue` array and `isSendingReadAcks` boolean had no synchronization, causing race conditions when:
- Multiple callers enqueue read receipts concurrently
- Check-then-act patterns on `isSendingReadAcks`
- Queue modifications during processing

## Solution
Extended the existing concurrent `DispatchQueue` (already used for `reachablePeers`) to protect read receipt state:

```swift
// sendReadReceipt() - wrap in barrier
queue.async(flags: .barrier) { [weak self] in
    self?.readQueue.append(QueuedRead(receipt: receipt, peerID: peerID))
    self?.processReadQueueIfNeeded()
}

// scheduleNextReadAck() - wrap callback in barrier
DispatchQueue.main.asyncAfter(deadline: .now() + readAckInterval) { [weak self] in
    self?.queue.async(flags: .barrier) { [weak self] in
        self?.isSendingReadAcks = false
        self?.processReadQueueIfNeeded()
    }
}
```

## Test plan
- [x] `concurrentReadReceiptEnqueue` - 100 concurrent enqueue operations
- [x] `readQueueProcessingUnderLoad` - concurrent enqueue during processing  
- [x] `isPeerReachableThreadSafety` - concurrent read access verification

merged_prs.title: fix(nip46): use getPublicKey() in nostrconnect flow to get actual user pubkey
merged_prs.body:
## Summary
- Fixes nostrconnect:// flow using bunker pubkey instead of user pubkey
- Aligns nostrconnect flow with bunker:// flow by calling getPublicKey() after connect

## Problem
The `blockUntilReadyNostrConnect()` method was incorrectly setting `userPubkey` to `response.event.pubkey`, which is the bunker's pubkey (the one signing the NIP-46 response event), not the actual user's pubkey.

This caused users logging in via nostrconnect:// to have their session associated with the wrong pubkey, leading to:
- Follows not loading (querying for wrong user's contacts)
- Profile data not loading correctly

## Solution
Call `getPublicKey()` to retrieve the actual user's pubkey from the bunker, just like the `bunker://` flow does.

Fixes #373

merged_prs.body:
## Summary

This PR introduces a modular, plugin-based architecture for LLM providers, replacing the monolithic switch statement in `LLMServiceFactory` with a scalable provider registry pattern that leverages AI SDK v6's `createProviderRegistry`.

### Key Changes

- **ProviderRegistry**: Central singleton managing provider lifecycle (registration, initialization, model creation)
- **Base Classes**: `BaseProvider`, `StandardProvider`, `AgentProvider` for different provider types
- **Individual Providers**: Each provider (OpenRouter, Anthropic, OpenAI, Ollama, Gemini CLI, Claude Code, Codex CLI) in its own file
- **Type Safety**: Strong typing with `ILLMProvider`, `ProviderMetadata`, and capability flags

### Architecture Overview

```
src/llm/providers/
├── types.ts                    # Provider interfaces and types
├── index.ts                    # Module exports and auto-registration
├── base/
│   ├── BaseProvider.ts         # Abstract base class
│   ├── StandardProvider.ts     # For AI SDK providers
│   └── AgentProvider.ts        # For agent-based providers
├── registry/
│   └── ProviderRegistry.ts     # Central registry singleton
├── standard/                   # Standard AI SDK providers
│   ├── OpenRouterProvider.ts
│   ├── AnthropicProvider.ts
│   ├── OpenAIProvider.ts
│   ├── OllamaProvider.ts
│   └── GeminiCliProvider.ts
└── agent/                      # Agent-based providers
    ├── ClaudeCodeProvider.ts
    └── CodexCliProvider.ts
```

### Benefits

1. **Scalability**: Add new providers by implementing `ILLMProvider` interface and adding to `ALL_PROVIDER_REGISTRATIONS`
2. **Separation of Concerns**: Each provider is self-contained with its own initialization logic
3. **Type Safety**: `ProviderMetadata` defines capabilities (streaming, tool calling, MCP support, etc.)
4. **Testability**: Providers can be tested in isolation
5. **AI SDK v6**: Properly leverages `createProviderRegistry` pattern

### Backward Compatibility

- `LLMServiceFactory` public API remains unchanged
- Existing code continues to work without modifications

merged_prs.body:
## Summary

Implements a modular Agent Supervision system that detects suspicious agent behaviors using heuristics, verifies them with an LLM supervisor, and re-engages agents with correction messages when issues are confirmed.

### Key Changes

- **New `src/agents/supervision/` module** with clean architecture:
  - `types.ts` - Core interfaces and types for the supervision system
  - `HeuristicRegistry.ts` - Pluggable registry for behavioral heuristics
  - `SupervisorLLMService.ts` - LLM-based verification service
  - `SupervisorOrchestrator.ts` - Main coordinator for checks

- **Three behavioral heuristics implemented**:
  1. **SilentAgentHeuristic** - Detects agents that complete without generating any output
  2. **DelegationClaimHeuristic** - Catches when agent says "I'll delegate to @agent" but doesn't call the delegate tool
  3. **PhaseAgentTodoHeuristic** - Ensures phase-managing agents set up a todo list before delegating

- **AgentExecutor integration** - Post-completion supervision check before publishing finalization events

- **LLM configuration** - Added `supervision` field to TenexLLMs with menu option in `tenex setup llm`

### Architecture

```
src/agents/supervision/
├── types.ts                    # Core interfaces
├── index.ts                    # Public exports
├── registerHeuristics.ts       # Default heuristic registration
├── SupervisorLLMService.ts     # LLM verification service
├── SupervisorOrchestrator.ts   # Main coordinator
└── heuristics/
    ├── index.ts
    ├── HeuristicRegistry.ts    # Pluggable registry
    ├── SilentAgentHeuristic.ts
    ├── DelegationClaimHeuristic.ts
    └── PhaseAgentTodoHeuristic.ts
```

### How It Works

1. When an agent completes, post-completion heuristics check the output
2. If a heuristic triggers (e.g., empty message), it builds evidence
3. The SupervisorLLM verifies if this is a real violation or false positive
4. If confirmed violation, a correction message is injected and the agent re-engages
5. Max 3 retries before allowing publication to prevent infinite loops

### Configuration

```bash
tenex setup llm
# Select "Supervision model" to configure which LLM verifies heuristics
```
